headline: Paid Notice: Deaths COURTENAY, ELAINE K.
summary: COURTENAY--Elaine K., 86, passed away April, 17th, 2014 in New York City. She was born in Rochester, NY on February 4th, 1928. She was raised in Barrington, Il where she graduated from high school. She attended Knox College in Illinois and Northwestern University before heading to New York City. She worked for General Cable of New York and AT&T. Elaine was an avid patron of the arts and founded Courtenay Artists, Inc., a talent agency, and she placed many famous singers and opera stars. She was preceded in death by her loving husband James Clark Courtenay, Jr., formerly of Louisville, KY, and her parents Mabel Barron and Charles Kerry. She is survived by her sister Linda Truxell of Livonia, MI; brothers Warren Kerry of Daytona Beach, FL, John Kerry of Treasure Island, FL, and several close nieces and nephews, and her beloved Papillon dog, Coquine Posy. The family wishes to express special thanks to her wonderful caregiver and friend, Candice Hutcherson. Services were held yesterday at the Embry-Bosse Funeral Home, 2723 Preston Highway, Louisville, KY followed by burial at Cave Hill Cemetery next to her beloved husband Jim. Memorial gifts may be made to Papillon Haven Rescue, c/o Jan Jordan, P.O. Box 20306, Hot Springs, AR 71903.

headline: Warner’s C.E.O. Is Bullish on the Big Screen

summary: The new team founded by Gene Haas, a co-owner of the Stewart-Haas Nascar team, would be the first based in the United States since 1976.

headline: Game of Drones
summary: It just might be the right time for a “Top Gun” sequel, considering we’re already on the highway to the danger zone.

headline: It’s Official: Yahoo’s Former No. 2 Made a Lot More Than His Boss
summary: Henrique de Castro, who was fired as Yahoo’s chief operating officer in January, received about $96 million for his 15 months of service. Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, was awarded only $62 million in roughly the same time period.

headline: Morgan Stanley Gets Most Relief From First-Quarter Earnings
summary: Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, presided over a far better start to the year than in 2013, and momentum seems to be building toward increasing the firm’s return on equity, writes Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews.

headline: Google Uses Algorithms to Create SLR-Like Photos
summary: Google is lifting up the hood of its new Lens Blur feature for its camera app, showing how the company can make a photo taken on a smartphone look like it was shot with an SLR camera.

headline: Uber Faces Rebukes in Europe
summary: The company’s global problems add to the bumps the company face in the United States, including opposition from taxi groups and driver complaints.

headline: Children’s Book to Soothe Parents of the College-Bound
summary: The investment company T. Rowe Price has published a rhyming picture book to help worried parents plan for the cost of sending their children to college.

headline: Cut the Clutter in Your Social Media Accounts
summary: There are simple ways to make platforms like Twitter and Facebook more useful, like making lists and trimming back groups.

headline: Deciding How Much Information and Flexibility to Give Employees
summary: One company offers employees the freedom to choose how many vacation days they take.

headline: Earnings and Sales From Google Disappoint
summary: As Internet users migrate to mobile devices, Google earns less on its ads, and as the dominant player, growth opportunities are increasingly rare.

headline: The Future of Facebook May Not Say ‘Facebook’
summary: The company’s strategy includes unbundling its mammoth social network into discrete and nimble components.

headline: When ‘Liking’ a Brand Online Voids the Right to Sue
summary: The food company General Mills added language to its website to alert customers that they cannot take legal action against the company if they download coupons, enter a contest or connect with it in other ways.

headline: The Best Photo Organizing App? I’m Still Looking
summary: A new entrant from Dropbox, Carousel, looked promising, but fell short. A raft of others all have strengths, but nothing offers everything you want.

headline: Facebook’s New Twist on Location Sharing Puts Users in Control
summary: The social network is rolling out a new feature, Nearby Friends, that allows mobile users to broadcast their general location to their friends. But simple privacy controls give users the power to decide how much more to share.

headline: Twitter Goes After a Facebook Cash Cow
summary: The social network will begin offering “app install ads,” which prompt smartphone users to try new games and other apps. The category has been a lucrative franchise for Facebook.

headline: New York Lawmakers Push to Raise Wages at Biggest Chains
summary: State Senator Daniel L. Squadron’s bill would raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour for employees of McDonald’s, Walmart and other businesses with yearly sales of $50 million or more.

headline: Workers Strike at Shoe Factory Over Benefits Dispute
summary: Workers at one of the world’s largest shoe manufacturers are on strike in the southern Chinese city of Dongguan in a dispute over benefits.

headline: In the Battle for Best Smartphone, Apple Still Beats Samsung
summary: Samsung’s newest phone, the Galaxy S5, is a very nice device. But it falls far short of Apple’s iPhone.

headline: Big Labels Take Aim at Pandora on Royalties
summary: The suit, filed by several big record companies on Thursday, accuses Pandora of violating common-law copyright protections for songs made before 1972.

headline: Protests Continue Against Dropbox After Appointment of Condoleezza Rice to Board
summary: After Dropbox appointed Condoleezza Rice, the former secretary of state, to its board of directors, some users have complained about her views on Internet surveillance.

headline: Perry Evans of Closely, on Craftsmanship and Early Rising
summary: Mr. Evans, chief and founder of Closely, a digital marketing firm, says he regularly awakes at 4 a.m. and spends “two hours every morning just calibrating what’s going on in my market.”

headline: Poison Pill’s Relevance in the Age of Shareholder Activism
summary: The lawsuit by Daniel S. Loeb against Sotheby’s may well be the tipping point in how far companies can go to defend themselves against shareholder activists, writes Steven M. Davidoff.

headline: Facebook’s Existential Crisis
summary: Is Facebook’s main service still relevant? An argument for why it feels fusty, and why Mark Zuckerberg seems to know it.

headline: Lululemon Officials Won’t Face Fraud Charges
summary: A federal judge on Friday issued final dismissals of lawsuits accusing Lululemon Athletica and company officials of defrauding shareholders by concealing defects in yoga pants.

headline: In Detroit, Judge Takes Offbeat Tack in Hiring Help
summary: Judge Steven W. Rhodes, who is overseeing this city’s bankruptcy case, is looking for someone who can analyze Detroit’s final bankruptcy plan.

headline: Mazda Recalls Older Tributes; VW Cites Fire Hazard in Some 2014 Models
summary: Baby Trend child restraints are also recalled because of defective buckles.

headline: Goldman, Citi, UBS ... and a Guy in an Office
summary: Paul J. Taubman has single-handedly accounted for $175 billion in deals over the last year, which has had Wall Street bankers buzzing with a mix of admiration and envy.

headline: Wheelies: The Welcome Back Maybach Edition
summary: Daimler has plans to bring back the Maybach brand; AT&T strikes a connected-car deal with a global automaker.

headline: Friends, and Influence, for Sale Online
summary: By using social media bots, celebrities, politicians and others can falsely inflate the number of friends and followers they have, possibly swaying public opinion about a new song — or a policy position.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, April 19
summary: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.

headline: Comcast’s Real Repairman
summary: David Cohen, Comcast’s executive vice president, is the point man for moving deals like the one for Time Warner Cable past regulatory hurdles.

headline: How to Get a Job at Google, Part 2
summary: New graduates may be intrigued by a hiring guru’s advice.

headline: 50 Years After the New York World’s Fair, Recalling a Vision of the Future
summary: Fairgoers share memories of family outings and moments of inspiration at the 1964 New York World’s Fair.

headline: Spurning Merger Approaches, AstraZeneca Pursues Own Path
summary: A deal with Pfizer would have been one of the biggest ever in the pharmaceutical industry. But whether such a deal makes sense is another matter.

headline: Interpublic Group Joins Ranks of Publishers With Report in Magazine Form
summary: A printed corporate citizenship report offers a look inside the advertising agency holding group.

headline: Kraft Macaroni and Cheese Enlists Start-Up to Help With Social Media
summary: Ditto Labs will search photos on Instagram, Tumblr and Twitter for Kraft Macaroni and Cheese products and use that information to develop marketing strategies.

headline: Starting in June, ‘Today’ Will Simulcast on SiriusXM
summary: NBC is announcing a deal with the satellite radio service that will bring all four hours of its franchise morning news show to radio.

headline: For Square, Making Money Remains a Challenge
summary: The question, analysts say, is how a payments start-up like Square can make itself into more than just another middleman.

headline: Banking Troubles, but Not a Word About Fraud Claims
summary: Readers object to euphemistic language about Bank of America’s legal woes.

headline: Ackman and Valeant Prepare Unusual Hostile Bid for Maker of Botox
summary: The effort to do a deal for Allergan, with a market value of $42 billion, puts together one of the most prominent hedge fund managers with Valeant, a drug maker known for its serial acquisitions.

headline: Aereo Case Will Shape TV’s Future
summary: A lot of people will be watching to see how the Supreme Court rules over the legality of Aereo because of what it could mean for the broader media ecosystem.

headline: GitHub Founder Resigns After Investigation
summary: The company said the investigation, into gender-based harassment, found no evidence of illegal practices.

headline: Netflix Says It Opposes Comcast’s Merger Bid
summary: It was the clearest statement on the merger from Netflix, nearly two months after it agreed to pay Comcast for a more direct connection to the cable operator’s Internet backbone.

headline: How Valeant Can Raise Its Bid for Botox Maker
summary: Valeant thinks it can cut $2.7 billion in costs from Allergan. With a single-digit tax rate, that could be worth $25 billion, writes Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.

headline: Hamish Maxwell, Philip Morris Empire Builder, Dies at 87
summary: Mr. Maxwell’s acquisitions helped Philip Morris become a consumer products giant.

headline: The Broadband Revolution Is Not Nigh
summary: A handful of cable companies still dominate this important market.

headline: Allergan Bid Adds to Spate of Pharmaceutical Deals
summary: Not counting the $45.6 billion bid for Allergan, mergers and acquisitions in the pharmaceutical industry stand at $47.1 billion so far this year, the highest year-to-date total since 2009.

headline: Wage Theft Across the Board
summary: An antitrust lawsuit filed by highly paid software engineers shows that the problem of wage theft is not confined to service-sector employees.

headline: Chernin Teams With AT&T in Online Video Investment Venture
summary: Peter Chernin, the former News Corporation president, has joined with AT&T to commit more than $500 million to a new investment vehicle for online video.

headline: Lytro Goes After Prosumer Photographers With New Camera
summary: The new Lytro Illum camera offers photographers a range of new features, while still allowing them to refocus a photo after the fact

headline: Companies Built on Sharing Balk When It Comes to Regulators
summary: In the sharing economy, safety issues, taxes and regulation have tended to be an afterthought. But now, regulators and officials are questioning the practices of start-ups like Airbnb and Uber.

headline: Ackman and Valeant Drum Up Stealth Activism
summary: William A. Ackman of Pershing Square Capital Management and Valeant Pharmaceuticals quietly set up to make a hostile bid for Allergan if necessary, Robert Cyran and Richard Beales write for Reuters Breakingviews.

headline: Seeking the Right Chemistry, Drug Makers Hunt for Mergers
summary: A takeover bid for Allergan, the maker of Botox, is part of an increasing pattern of large pharmaceutical industries shoring up their businesses through acquisition.

headline: Up for Discussion: How to Create an Advisory Board
summary: Should advisers be compensated?

headline: Orbitz Adds to Third-Party Booking Credit Card Options
summary: Orbitz becomes the latest third-party booking site to offer a credit card.

headline: In Allergan Bid, a Question of Insider Trading
summary: William A. Ackman is sitting on a paper profit of more than $1 billion, leaving some to wonder whether the windfall comes as result of what feels like insider trading.

headline: Hotel Brands Share Real Estate, Sometimes Uneasily
summary: As developers squeeze into metropolitan areas, more hotel brands are sharing buildings and amenities while trying to maintain their individuality.

headline: 30,000 Golf Carts and 4,000 Heavy Duty Ford Trucks Recalled
summary: The golf carts were recalled after an out-of-control unit injured its user; the trucks were recalled for a transmission defect.

headline: Taming the Digital Wild West
summary: The web may be changing business, but regulations still apply.

headline: Some Setbacks for the Sharing Economy
summary: San Francisco is suing two landlords, saying they illegally evicted tenants so they could make their apartments into places for well-heeled tourists. New York State is investigating Uber for price-gouging during storms.

headline: At Stake in the Aereo Case Is How We Watch TV
summary: The case has a little bit of everything, including the first big test at the Supreme Court of who owns and has rights to things stored in the cloud.

headline: Gilead Revenue Soars on Hepatitis C Drug
summary: Gilead Sciences reported $2.3 billion in sales of Sovaldi, a new hepatitis C drug that has raised an outcry over its $1,000-a-pill price.

headline: Justices Skeptical of Aereo’s Business
summary: Television broadcasters are challenging Aereo, an Internet start-up that uses arrays of small antennas to stream over-the-air signals to subscribers.

headline: A Million New Wireless Subscriptions Lift AT&T Revenue, but Profit Is Flat
summary: The telecommunications company’s first-quarter earnings were flat compared with the previous year, but its revenue grew 4 percent, to $32.5 billion.

headline: With a Mouthful, A&W Hopes to Draw Baby Boomers’ Offspring
summary: The restaurant chain, which peaked in the 1960s and ’70s, hopes a campaign that includes a 304-character hashtag will attract the younger generation.

headline: At the Auto Show, Vehicles With a New York Connection
summary: Two gubernatorial limousines, a classic Corvette and a custom Harley-Davidson have come down from Albany.

headline: Strict Cost-Cutters Who Want to Spend $45 Billion on a Takeover
summary: Valeant’s chief, J. Michael Pearson, has slimmed down the pharmaceuticals company, but been an aggressive acquirer, spending more than $19 billion on companies.

headline: Openings, Events and Sales for the Week of April 24
summary: Gap and P.S. — I Made This host a D.I.Y. party, spring sales at Scoop NYC and more.

headline: Google Plus Boss Vic Gundotra Leaving Google
summary: Mr. Gundotra, who has been a strong proponent for Google’s social network, did not detail what he planned to do after leaving the company.

headline: Cellphone Cases to Prepare You for Anything, Even a Flat Tire
summary: These cases can add speakers, encryption, a hard drive and even a bike repair kit.

headline: An iPhone Engineer-Turned-Game Maker Shares His Apple Story
summary: Francisco Tolmasky’s experience building software for the original iPhone offers a rare window into the company’s start-up-like product development.

headline: Apple’s Stock Split: Attracting the Wrong Crowd?
summary: Although splitting shares should make no difference, one study suggests it creates a shift toward short-term investors.

headline: Investors Enthusiastic About Zimmer’s Deal for Rival
summary: Zimmer’s stock value soared after it announced that it would acquire Biomet as shareholders bet on growth in the market for medical devices, Robert Cyran writes in Reuters Breakingviews.

headline: Companies Back Initiative to Support OpenSSL and Other Open-Source Projects
summary: The Heartlbleed bug that weakened the security of millions of web servers and Internet-connected devices also exposed a flaw in open-source software maintenance that many have promised to fix.

headline: 2 Women Who Offer Life Lessons in Very Different Ways
summary: Two new network television shows, “Bad Teacher” and “Black Box,” feature female characters who are torn in various ways.

headline: Bieber Apology Over Shrine Visit Falls Flat in China
summary: Despite efforts by the pop star Justin Bieber to make amends after his visit to the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo, Chinese online commenters seemed skeptical about his sincerity.

headline: The Cloud Industry Needs Aereo to Win. But Consumers Need Something Better.
summary: The Supreme Court battle over Aereo could cast a pall over the cloud computing industry. For consumers, though, Aereo is too inefficient to become a useful service.

headline: Facebook Profit Tripled in First Quarter
summary: The company reported 1.28 billion monthly users, most on mobile devices, and easily exceeded analysts’ expectations for revenue and profit.

headline: Zimmer Holdings to Buy Biomet for $13.35 Billion
summary: The deal is just the latest in a spree of consolidations in the health care industry, driven in part by the Affordable Care Act and an aging U.S. population.

headline: Balloon Lets Builders Check Out Future Towers’ Views
summary: A big white balloon seen hovering over parts of Manhattan this week is photographing potential views from skyscrapers for architects and real estate developers.

headline: After Blast, East Harlem Tenants Are Worried About Dust
summary: Concerns over asbestos-laced grime in their apartments have prompted some of the families displaced after a deadly March 12 gas explosion to file suit against the landlord and the city.

headline: A Ticket to Fame, With Relish
summary: Lloyd Handwerker discusses his documentary “Famous Nathan,” about Nathan Handwerker, his grandfather, who started Coney Island’s quintessential hot-dog stand.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Met Plans, Lupita Nyong’o’s Newest “Award” and the Rise of Faux Shopping
summary: Plus, the fall of Nike’s chicest accessory, the new Barneys shopping app and more from the week in style.

headline: A Supplement Retailer Pumps Up Consumers
summary: A new advertising campaign by GNC called “Beat average” plays to the unwillingness of many people to identify as below the median.

headline: Tech Giants Settle Antitrust Hiring Suit
summary: Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe reached an agreement with plaintiffs over charges that the companies conspired not to hire one another’s employees.

headline: Sotheby’s Battle Heats Up
summary: The fight between Sotheby’s and Daniel S. Loeb is heading to its final stages. | The Justice Department is looking to strike a deal with Bank of America. | Loosening insider trading laws. | Zimmer’s $13.35 billion deal for Biomet.

headline: The New York Athletic Club: A Proud Sponsor of Meb Keflezighi
summary: Corporate sponsorships have rendered a function of the elite athletic club obsolete, making the N.Y.A.C.’s relationship with the Boston Marathon winner something of a relic.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 25-May 1
summary: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

headline: Loosening the Rules on Insider Trading
summary: An appellate court seems inclined to change the rules on insider trading in a way that will make it easier for professional traders to escape liability.

headline: Amid Overhaul, Case Questions Agency’s Foster Care
summary: As Texas Child Protective Services is working on an overhaul, a trial is set to hear a case brought by an advocacy group that says the agency keeps children in foster care too long.

headline: Answering Readers’ Questions About the Baseball Maps
summary: Although Facebook data must be taken with a grain of salt, the results broadly match up with findings from other sources.

headline: Buffett Punts on Pay
summary: The Oracle of Omaha gives excessive executive compensation a pass when he had the chance to take a stand.

headline: Writing in a Nonstop World
summary: Our interactions with computers have gone from brief and long to frequent and glancing. That difference is changing how we write, how we relate to each other, and how we build things. What happens when the interactions become nonstop?

headline: Amazon’s Shrinking Profit Sets Off a Seismic Shock to Its Shares
summary: For a second quarter in a row, the Internet retailer’s stock fell sharply after its earnings report, suggesting that investors may be growing wary.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Jaguar and Mazda Issue Recalls
summary: Some recent Harley models may have a fueling defect; some Jaguar models are prone to a suspension issue; Mazda recalls cars with regenerative braking.

headline: A Walmart Fortune, Spreading Charter Schools
summary: The foundation led by the family that built Walmart has spent more than $1 billion on some of the fastest-growing, and most divisive, trends in education.

headline: As Parents Make Their Own Baby Food, Industry Tries to Adapt
summary: Sales of commercially prepared baby food have been steadily falling since 2005 as parents take a do-it-yourself approach.

headline: Netflix vs. Amazon, and the New Economics of Television
summary: To succeed today, you need to control either the content or the pipes.

headline: For Drugs That Save Lives, a Steep Cost
summary: Cost is the great taboo in U.S. health care. And we pay dearly.

headline: Oh, How They Like to Dish
summary: A conversation with Liz Smith, a gossip columnist, and Jess Cagle, editorial director of People magazine about celebrity, ambition and the difference between gossip and news.

headline: A Student-Data Collector Drops Out
summary: The demise of inBloom, after just 15 months in operation, offers a cautionary tale for purveyors of education technology software.

headline: Should a Chimp Be Able to Sue Its Owner?
summary: Steven Wise is arguing for the legal “personhood” of chimps and other animals. And no one is laughing him out of the courtroom.

headline: New Challenges Chip Away at Cable’s Pillar of Profit
summary: A future where consumers will be able to assemble an à la carte menu of entertainment suddenly seems much closer.

headline: Few Consumers Are Buying Premise of Mobile Wallets
summary: While numerous solutions are in the market, none have won widespread adoption, as consumers are either unaware of the option — or unimpressed by it.

headline: A Young Mayor Who Likes to Share His View From the Top
summary: Personal photographs taken by Mayor Eric Garcetti shed light on Los Angeles and new ways for politicians to use social media.

headline: When Amazon Collects Sales Tax, Some Shoppers Head Elsewhere
summary: Research shows that many of these consumers are going to Amazon’s online competitors to spend their money.

headline: AT&T Plans to Provide Wireless Internet for Airplanes
summary: The company said that by late 2015, it would build a new air-to-ground network based on 4G LTE, the same type of cellular technology that many of the latest smartphones use to connect to the Internet.

headline: Chef Seeks to Buy Contessa Food Business
summary: Ina Garten, the celebrity chef known as the Barefoot Contessa, says she is putting together an investor group to buy the frozen food business that carries her name from Contessa Premium Foods.

headline: Is It Time to Broaden the Definition of Insider Trading?
summary: William A. Ackman’s actions in the bid for Allergan have raised questions about how well the insider-trading rules have protected investors, Peter J. Henning writes in White Collar Watch.

headline: Alliant Techsystems’ Break-Up and the Return of the Morris Trust
summary: Alliant Techsystems chose to break itself apart through a rarely used corporate maneuver known as the Morris trust, meant to avoid incurring taxes.

headline: Yahoo Chief’s Pay Tied to Another Company’s Performance
summary: Such paydays illustrate that it is often good fortune rather than individual performance that account for the bulk of executive pay, Steven Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.

headline: Buffett Bites Back
summary: Abstaining on Coke’s executive compensation plan sent a loud message that Berkshire Hathaway didn’t approve, he now says. Really?

headline: New York State Makes New Efforts to Combat Payday Lenders
summary: Benjamin M. Lawsky, New York State’s top financial regulator, is sending cease-and-desist letters to 20 companies suspected of making illegal payday loans.

headline: Pfizer Most Likely Just the Tip of the Tax Sword
summary: The biggest charm of Pfizer’s offer for AstraZeneca lies in switching to a lower-tax domicile, a strategy that is sure to be duplicated, Robert Cyran writes for Reuters Breakingviews.

headline: The Quirk That Bolsters Allergan’s Defense
summary: In any maneuvering around a proxy contest, the $45.6 billion takeover target has an advantage and it has time, writes Steven M. Davidoff in the Deal Professor column.

headline: Standing on the Sidelines With Virtual Reality
summary: Imagine sitting on the sideline of a football game or hanging out next to a drummer of your favorite concert. Next3D, a movie company in Los Angeles, hopes to make this a reality by merging 3-D film technologies and virtual reality headsets.

headline: Doximity, an Online Network for Doctors, Raises $54 Million
summary: The money, which brings Doximity’s total financing to $81 million, highlights investor appetite for relatively specialized social networks.

headline: Yahoo to Offer TV-Style Comedy Series on the Web
summary: The move plunges Yahoo directly into the world of original programming, joining the likes of Amazon, Netflix and others to challenge traditional TV producers for viewers’ attention.

headline: How Tax Laws Distort the Pfizer Deal
summary: We don’t know if Pfizer is targeting a British rival because the combined firm will be more efficient or because of the tax savings, Victor Fleischer writes in his Standard Deduction column.

headline: Anonymous Chatting, Through a Simple Service
summary: An entrepreneur has cobbled together a simple and free service called Anonyfish that allows people to send private, anonymous messages to each other, mainly as a companion to the Secret app.

headline: Spotify Teams With Sprint on a Mobile Music Plan
summary: The deal gives Sprint customers in the United States free access to Spotify’s paid version for up to six months, and further discounts beyond that.

headline: Apple and Samsung Cite, and Rebut, Internal Memos in Patent Case
summary: Lawyers for Apple and Samsung presented closing arguments in the latest billion-dollar patent dispute between the mobile phone and tablet makers.

headline: The Push to Regulate the ‘Sharing Economy’
summary: Readers criticize New York State’s attorney general for supporting regulations that they fear will stifle innovation.

headline: Europe’s Antitrust Chief Censures Google’s Motorola Mobility Over Key Patents
summary: The ruling is the strongest statement yet by an antitrust authority against the use of vital patents for mobile digital devices to stymie rivals.

headline: A Corporate Paean to Frank Lloyd Wright
summary: A museum replicating a lab in the Research Tower at S. C. Johnson’s headquarters in Racine, Wis., is opening as part of an eight-year, $30 million restoration project.

headline: Reinventing Rye Playland Ignites an Unexpected Battle
summary: Neighbors of the Art Deco amusement park, built in 1928 and run by Westchester County, object to planned additions like a large field house.

headline: Pfizer’s Move Poses Challenge. Here’s a Solution.
summary: The extremes to which companies go to minimize their tax liability suggests it’s time for a new approach, one focusing on shareholders instead.
